summary: This document is primarily an email chain from August 2019 concerning scheduling a telephonic court hearing for inmate Wilbert Kitson Turner at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a forwarded request for a psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein from late July 2019. The email shows coordination between Bureau of Prisons staff and a defense attorney to arrange the hearing. This document is a collection of email correspondence and a court notice regarding inmate Nicholas 'Nick' Turner's conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It involves legal staff, attorneys, and federal prosecutors discussing a cell phone allegation, poor cell conditions, and the scheduling of a status conference for Turner's civil case. This document contains email correspondence from July-August 2019 regarding conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) for an inmate named 'Nick' and later regarding Jeffrey Epstein's telephone account and news articles about his suicide and will. It shows communication between Bureau of Prisons staff, federal prosecutors, and defense attorneys. This document is a collection of emails and news clippings from August and December 2019. The primary content is a breaking news email about Jeffrey Epstein signing a $577 million will two days before his death, witnessed by a lawyer who represented El Chapo. It also includes other news clippings and internal Bureau of Prisons emails regarding visits to Epstein's cell and a missing psychological observation report. This document is a prison psychology observation log for inmate Jeffrey Epstein covering July 24-30, 2019, along with an email forwarding the log. The log details his activities, meals, and status while on psych observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The email metadata shows it was sent from an Associate Warden to BOP officials. This document is a prison observation log and related email concerning Jeffrey Epstein's psychological observation/suicide watch from July 24-30, 2019, while he was incarcerated. It includes a meal/shower chart, handwritten observation notes, and metadata for an email transmitting the log. This document is a forwarded email chain among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) legal staff discussing a court order in a separate criminal case (USA v. Conyers et al.). It includes a suicide watch/psych observation log for an inmate (likely Jeffrey Epstein) and an email about a court order requiring a mental health treatment update for another inmate, Anthony Scott. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) legal staff and a federal prosecutor regarding a court order in a criminal case (USA v. Conyers et al). It also includes a separate email from a federal prosecutor requesting a visit to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) to inspect areas related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. This document contains email correspondence from August and November-December 2019. It includes a request from SDNY prosecutors to visit the MCC after Jeffrey Epstein's death, a journalist inquiry about charges against MCC staff, and internal BOP discussions about a Miami Herald report on systemic sexual abuse at a women's prison in Florida, linking it to broader BOP dysfunction highlighted by Epstein's death. This document is a series of email exchanges between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials discussing a Miami Herald article and subsequent lawsuit about systemic sexual abuse at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex. The emails involve internal coordination on how to respond to inquiries from the Office of the Solicitor (OS) regarding statistics on sexual abuse allegations within BOP facilities. This document contains email chains from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) discussing two main topics: 1) A request for statistics on sexual abuse allegations in BOP facilities following a Miami Herald article about systemic abuse at Coleman Correctional Complex, and 2) Internal communications regarding a visit by the US Attorney's Office to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It reveals BOP's internal response to media inquiries and coordination for an official investigation visit. This document contains a detailed timeline of events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's suicide in the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019, and a subsequent internal Bureau of Prisons memo discussing changes to suicide watch protocols following his death. It includes minute-by-minute logs of the incident and official notifications. This document contains email correspondence from December 2019 regarding a Miami Herald article about systemic sexual abuse at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, and includes a forwarded email from August 2019 regarding a psychological observation of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It shows BOP officials discussing media inquiries about sexual abuse statistics and contains a suicide watch/observation log. This document is a Bureau of Prisons email chain and attached psychological observation log for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering the period from July 8 to July 10, 2019. It details his status on psychological observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York and includes internal BOP communications regarding his case. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons emails and a detailed timeline of events surrounding the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes a minute-by-minute log of the discovery, medical response, notifications, and subsequent investigation, as well as emails arranging a tour of the facility for US Attorney's Office staff. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY). It includes a request for SDNY officials to tour the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Jeffrey Epstein's death, and subsequent internal BOP emails regarding a media inquiry about sewage flooding and staffing issues at the MCC in the wake of Epstein's suicide. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding media inquiries about MCC staff charges related to Jeffrey Epstein's death, and separate emails between a BOP official and Jeffrey Epstein's attorney regarding the delivery of a CPAP machine to Epstein while in custody. It shows internal BOP coordination on press strategy and logistical details of Epstein's medical care. This document contains email correspondence between Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, and Bureau of Prisons official Adam Johnson regarding administrative matters for Epstein's incarceration, including the approval of a paralegal and delivery of a CPAP machine. It also includes forwarded Google Alerts about prison news and Epstein's death. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) arranging a tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The SDNY prosecutors request to see the suicide watch area, SHU, and Epstein's cordoned-off cell, indicating an investigation into the circumstances of his death. This document contains email correspondence between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding a medical records request for Jeffrey Epstein and a press inquiry about MCC staff charges, along with Epstein's detailed medical records from July 2019 at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The medical records show Epstein reporting health issues including numbness, sleep apnea, and lack of medication in the weeks before his death. A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) clinical encounter notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, covering the period from his intake in early July 2019 to July 24, 2019. The documents detail his medical history, routine care, and crucially, the assessment of injuries sustained on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a rope around his neck and later insinuated his cellmate was involved. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and subsequent health encounters from July 6 to July 30, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York (NYM). It includes detailed health assessments, vital signs, medical orders, and notes from multiple providers, documenting his physical and mental health status while in custody. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons medical, dental, and psychological records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (Reg #76318-054) from July 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NY). It includes health assessments, dietary requests, medication lists, dental exams, and a psychological evaluation regarding his competency for a disciplinary process related to a self-mutilation incident report. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical contact notes from July 25-29, 2019, detailing daily mental health observations of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The notes focus on his psychological state, complaints about Special Housing Unit (SHU) conditions, his inability to recall how he sustained neck injuries, and his interactions with staff and attorneys. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychology service reports from July 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a post-suicide watch report, suicide risk assessments, and clinical intervention notes following an incident where Epstein was found with a string around his neck. The reports document his psychological evaluations, his claims of memory loss about the incident, his fear for safety, and his eventual removal from suicide watch. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-10, 2019, including a suicide risk assessment, diagnostic formulation, and clinical intervention notes. The records show Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from court, was assessed as having low suicide risk, and made various requests about his jail conditions while awaiting his bail hearing. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment forms for Jeffrey Epstein, conducted shortly after his July 2019 arrest. It includes suicide risk assessments, intake screening, and risk of sexual abusiveness evaluations, all concluding he was at low risk, mentally stable, and denied suicidal ideation. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons medical records and related correspondence for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, covering lab results, treatment refusals, dental exams, and a clinical encounter detailing an injury assessment after he was found with a rope around his neck. It includes an email requesting these records for the period July 1-24, 2019. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services clinical encounter records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and follow-up medical evaluations at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019, shortly after his arrest and before his death. It details his medical history, complaints, physical exams, and prescribed treatments. This document contains Bureau of Prisons health services and psychology records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, including medical examinations, vital signs, medication orders, and a detailed suicide risk assessment following an incident where he was found with a string around his neck. The records show Epstein's medical conditions, psychological evaluations, and his placement on suicide watch. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-12, 2019, including suicide risk assessments, clinical intervention notes, and diagnostic formulations. The records show Epstein was placed on psychological observation after returning from court, was assessed as low suicide risk, and details his complaints about jail conditions while awaiting his bail hearing. This document contains a Bureau of Prisons suicide risk assessment and a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 9, 2019, while he was in pre-trial detention at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). The suicide risk assessment, prompted by a court proceeding the previous day, concludes Epstein was at low acute risk and not on suicide watch, noting his denial of suicidality and future orientation. A separate assessment rates him as low risk for sexual abusiveness in the facility. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical and psychological intake records for Jeffrey Epstein from July-August 2019, including his initial psychological screening, lab results, treatment refusals, chronic care visits, and the emergency resuscitation report from August 10, 2019, the day he was found unresponsive in his cell. It shows his medical condition and mental state in the weeks before his death. A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 23-30, 2019, documenting his health complaints, treatments, and a notable injury incident. The records detail an injury to his neck on July 23, subsequent neurological symptoms, and his refusal to explain the cause, hinting at his cellmate's involvement. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and subsequent medical evaluations at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York (NYM) in July 2019. The records detail his medical history, complaints, physical exams, and prescribed treatments in the weeks leading up to his death. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his intake medical screening on July 9, 2019, and subsequent medical care up to August 23, 2019. It includes detailed physical and mental health assessments, vital signs, medication orders, and notes on his medical conditions and allergies. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (Reg #76318-054) covering his incarceration at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM MCC) from July 6, 2019, to August 23, 2019. It includes medical assessments, diagnoses, medication logs, dental records, and psychological evaluations, including suicide risk assessments and a clinical intervention session. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes and reports from late July to early August 2019, detailing mental health assessments of Jeffrey Epstein while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The notes focus on his mental status, suicide risk assessments, and competency evaluations following an incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a string around his neck in the SHU. The overall assessment concludes he is psychologically stable, not suicidal, and competent to proceed with disciplinary processes. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes and a post-suicide watch report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 24-28, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM). The notes detail his mental status, his claims of no memory regarding an incident that left marks on his neck, his complaints about Special Housing Unit (SHU) conditions, and his interactions with staff and inmate companions. The reports assess his suicide risk as low and step him down from suicide watch to psychological observation. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-24, 2019, while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and administrative notes, culminating in the July 23, 2019 incident where Epstein was found with a string around his neck and placed on suicide watch. The records detail his mental state, denials of suicidality, and the unclear circumstances of the neck incident. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment forms for Jeffrey Epstein, including a Diagnostic and Care Level Formulation and multiple Suicide Risk Assessments conducted on July 9-10, 2019. The assessments were performed after Epstein returned from a court proceeding and was placed on precautionary psychological observation. The psychologist found Epstein had no mental health diagnosis, denied suicidal ideation, and was assessed as having low acute suicide risk. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological and medical assessment records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, while he was incarcerated at MCC New York. It includes a suicide risk assessment, a risk of sexual abusiveness evaluation, an intake screening, and a medical lab report. The psychological assessments conclude Epstein was at low risk for suicide and sexual abusiveness, was future-oriented, and denied any suicidal ideation or mental health history. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, including HIV counseling documentation and multiple medical treatment refusal forms. It also includes a Washington Post article from September 2019 about the 2020 Democratic presidential primary, focusing on generational change among candidates. This document is a newsletter from The Washington Post's Daily 202 briefing covering various political news topics including Trump family dynamics, Brexit negotiations, Afghanistan peace talks, Hong Kong protests, and domestic U.S. politics. It contains no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein or his case. This document is an email newsletter from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' dated September 9, 2019. It contains summaries of news stories, including coverage of the #MeToo movement's reporting on Harvey Weinstein and a report on Jeffrey Epstein's financial ties to elite universities like MIT and Harvard. This document is a forwarded email chain from September 2019. The main content is a Washington Post newsletter ('The Daily 202') covering the 2020 Democratic presidential primary, focusing on generational dynamics among candidates. It also includes sections on international affairs (Afghanistan peace talks, Brexit, Hong Kong protests) and domestic U.S. politics. Notably, a forwarded email at the end references Jeffrey Epstein's connections to elite universities (MIT, Harvard) and the resignation of MIT Media Lab director Joi Ito over Epstein donations. This document contains email correspondence among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's mental capacity for disciplinary proceedings and a detailed timeline of events surrounding his death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes internal communications and a suicide timeline report. This document contains a suicide watch/psychiatric observation log for an inmate, followed by email metadata regarding a 'Psych Observation' for Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019. The email was sent from a prison official to other recipients, indicating internal communication about Epstein's status while in custody.

events.title: Psychological Observation of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on psychological observation at MCC New York. A log was maintained tracking his meals, liquids, and shower activity.

events.title: Scheduled Telephonic Court Hearing for Wilbert Turner
events.description: A telephonic hearing for inmate Wilbert Kitson Turner's federal civil case was scheduled with Judge Steven Weissman of the SDNY. Coordination involved ensuring a specific attorney conference room was available at MCC NY.

events.title: Email Forwarding Psychological Observation Log
events.description: An email was sent forwarding a psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein from late July 2019, indicating internal BOP communication regarding his status.

events.title: Rescheduled Status Conference for Turner v. Ulloa
events.description: An in-person status conference for the case Turner v. Ulloa, et al. was rescheduled from August 9 to August 8, 2019, at 10:00 a.m. The pro se plaintiff (Turner) was to participate by telephone.

events.title: Nick Turner Placed in SHU
events.description: Inmate Nick Turner was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC-NY based on an allegation of possessing a cell phone.

events.title: Email Coordination on SHU Conditions
events.description: Multiple emails between MCC staff attorneys and federal prosecutors were exchanged to schedule a call to discuss the conditions of Nick Turner's confinement in SHU, including a leaking toilet and seized legal documents.

events.title: Inmate 'Nick' placed in SHU
events.description: An inmate named Nick was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the MCC based on an allegation of cell phone possession.

events.title: Request to establish Epstein's phone account
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella emails the MCC to request help for Jeffrey Epstein to establish a telephone account, noting the process was started but not finished.

events.title: Barr announces probe into Epstein suicide irregularities
events.description: Attorney General William Barr states investigators are uncovering 'serious irregularities' at the NYC federal lockup where Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide.

events.title: News on Epstein's will signed before suicide
events.description: A news article reports Jeffrey Epstein signed a will worth $577 million two days before his suicide, with an El Chapo lawyer as a witness.

events.title: Epstein signs will
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a will declaring he was worth $577 million, witnessed by lawyer Mariel Colon Miro.

events.title: Epstein's suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself in a federal jail.

events.title: Epstein's first suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's first reported suicide effort in July; video surveillance footage from that time is reported missing.

events.title: Manafort charges dismissed
events.description: New York Judge Maxwell Wiley dismissed state fraud charges against Paul Manafort on double-jeopardy grounds.

events.title: Ebbers granted compassionate release
events.description: Federal Judge Valerie E. Caproni granted a compassionate release to former WorldCom CEO Bernard Ebbers.

events.title: MCC visit scheduled
events.description: A visit was arranged for the USAO to see the 2nd floor psych observation area, 9th floor SHU, and Epstein's cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Start of Psych Observation for Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein placed on psychology observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: End of Psych Observation Period
events.description: The documented psychology observation period for Jeffrey Epstein ends.

events.title: Email Forwarding Observation Log
events.description: Associate Warden Charisma Edge emails the psychology observation log for Jeffrey Epstein (dated July 24-30, 2019) to BOP officials.

events.title: End of Psych Observation for Epstein
events.description: The psychological observation period for Jeffrey Epstein concluded.

events.title: Observation Log Email Transmitted
events.description: An email was sent containing the psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein from July 24-30, 2019.

events.title: Court Order for Mental Health Update
events.description: Judge Valerie E. Caproni signs an order in case USA v. Conyers et al., requiring the government to provide an update on inmate Anthony Scott's mental health treatment by March 10, 2020.

events.title: BOP Email Discussion
events.description: BOP attorneys Stephanie Scannell-Vessella, Christina Kelley, and others discuss the court order and decide to contact AUSA Samson Enzer directly for follow-up.

events.title: Court Order in USA v. Conyers et al
events.description: Judge Valerie E. Caproni orders the government to provide an update on defendant Anthony Scott's mental health treatment by March 10, 2020.

events.title: Prosecutor Request to Visit MCC
events.description: Federal prosecutors from the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office request a visit to the Metropolitan Correctional Center to inspect the psych observation/suicide watch area, the SHU, and Jeffrey Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanged in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: SDNY Request to Visit MCC
events.description: SDNY prosecutors request a visit to the MCC to see Epstein's cell and suicide watch areas, indicating ongoing investigation into his death.

events.title: AP Inquiry on MCC Staff Charges
events.description: Associated Press reporter Michael Sisak inquires about two MCC employees about to be charged regarding lapses the night of Epstein's death.

events.title: Miami Herald Report on Prison Abuse
events.description: Miami Herald publishes investigation into systemic sexual abuse of female inmates by male officers at Coleman Federal Correctional Complex in Florida.

events.title: BOP Internal Discussion on Abuse Report
events.description: Internal BOP email chain discusses the Miami Herald report, with officials scrambling to provide data on sexual abuse allegations from 2014-2019.

events.title: Miami Herald publishes article on sexual abuse at Coleman
events.description: Miami Herald publishes an investigation alleging systemic sexual abuse of female inmates by male officers at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex women's work camp.

events.title: DOJ/BOP internal email chain regarding abuse allegations
events.description: Internal email correspondence among BOP and DOJ officials discussing how to respond to inquiries from the Office of the Solicitor about the Miami Herald article and a related lawsuit.

events.title: Lawsuit filed by fourteen women against BOP
events.description: Fourteen women file a lawsuit under their real names against the United States over sexual abuse endured at the Coleman prison camp, seeking compensation and an overhaul.

events.title: BOP internal discussion on sexual abuse statistics
events.description: Internal BOP email chain discussing how to respond to DOJ inquiries about sexual abuse statistics following the Miami Herald article.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found dead at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanged in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: Scheduled US Attorney's Office tour of MCC
events.description: US Attorney Geoffrey Berman and staff scheduled to tour the MCC's SHU, suicide watch areas, and Epstein's cell.

events.title: Internal coordination for MCC tour
events.description: Emails sent to coordinate the upcoming visit by the US Attorney's Office to the MCC following Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein's Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein spends the day in attorney conferences. His cellmate, Reyes Efrain, departs for court in the morning.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, a body alarm is activated. Staff find Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR is initiated, EMS is called, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital where he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am.

events.title: Official Notifications and Investigation Launch
events.description: Following the death, the FBI, AUSA, Judge Berman, Epstein's next of kin (brother), and the media are notified. The OIG is contacted and an investigation begins. Computer hard drives are removed from the SHU.

events.title: OIG Agents Collect Evidence
events.description: OIG Agents John Kerwin and Guido Modano arrive, and Kerwin departs with two computers from the Special Housing Unit (SHU).

events.title: Staff Recall and Continued FBI Presence
events.description: A staff recall is conducted, and the FBI arrives and departs multiple times throughout the day and evening.

events.title: Senior BOP Officials Arrive for Review
events.description: Multiple senior BOP officials, including the Northeast Regional Director and national program coordinators, arrive at the institution.

events.title: Internal BOP Suicide Prevention Memo Discussed
events.description: Heidi Kugler emails Hugh Hurwitz and Alison Leukefeld about a memo addressing changes to suicide watch protocols, noting that wardens were keeping inmates on watch longer than psychologists advised after Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Psych Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on psychological observation from 6 pm on July 8, 2019, until 9 am on July 10, 2019.

events.title: Miami Herald Article on Prison Abuse
events.description: Miami Herald publishes article detailing systemic sexual abuse at Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, leading to a lawsuit by 14 women.

events.title: BOP Email Discussion on Abuse Statistics
events.description: BOP officials correspond via email regarding questions from the Office of the Solicitor about sexual abuse statistics at BOP facilities.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on psychological observation/suicide watch at MCC New York, beginning at 6:00 PM.

events.title: Psychological Observation Period Ends
events.description: The scheduled psychological observation period for Jeffrey Epstein ended at 9:00 AM.

events.title: Email with Observation Log Sent
events.description: Lanett N'Diaye sent an email with the attached psychological observation log for Jeffrey Epstein covering July 8-10, 2019.

events.title: Follow-up Email on Epstein's Status
events.description: Lee Plourde sent an email to multiple BOP staff regarding 'Epstein, Jeffrey Reg. No. 76318-054X'.

events.title: Epstein's last full day
events.description: Epstein meets with attorneys throughout the day. His cellmate, Reyes Efrain, departs for court and does not return.

events.title: Evidence collection by OIG
events.description: OIG Agents John Kerwin and Guido Modano arrive at MCC, remove two computer hard drives from the SHU, and depart with them.

events.title: High-level BOP review team arrival
events.description: National suicide prevention and sex offender program coordinators, a regional director, and a correctional services administrator arrive at MCC for review.

events.title: Scheduled US Attorney's Office tour
events.description: A tour of the MCC SHU, suicide watch areas, and Epstein's cell is scheduled for US Attorney Geoffrey Berman and his staff.

events.title: Scheduled US Attorney Tour of MCC
events.description: The US Attorney for the SDNY and his staff schedule a tour of the MCC's 2nd floor psych observation/suicide watch area, 9th floor SHU, and Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: Media Inquiry on MCC Sewage Flooding
events.description: Reporter Jake Offenhartz inquires about raw sewage flooding jail cells at the MCC, female detainees being asked to clean it, visitation denials due to staffing, and BOP's steps after Epstein's suicide.

events.title: BOP Confirms Sewage Backup at MCC
events.description: The BOP Office of Public Affairs confirms a sewage backup was repaired and cleaned, and visitation was temporarily delayed due to staffing.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Referenced as the event that prompted the US Attorney's tour and media questions about MCC staffing and conditions.

events.title: AP Inquiry about MCC Staff Charges
events.description: Reporter Michael Sisak contacts the BOP inquiring if their attorney is representing two MCC employees about to be charged regarding lapses the night of Epstein's death.

events.title: CPAP Machine Approval for Epstein
events.description: BOP official Adam Johnson informs Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, that medical staff can accept a CPAP machine for Epstein, with specific delivery instructions.

events.title: Schedule for CPAP Delivery
events.description: Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, informs the BOP he will deliver the CPAP machine and asks them to notify Mr. Yannone.

events.title: Paralegal Application Submission
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella submits an application for paralegal Samanta Honigman to work on Epstein's case to BOP official Adam Johnson.

events.title: CPAP Machine Delivery Arranged
events.description: Arrangements are made for the delivery of a CPAP machine for inmate Jeffrey Epstein to the prison medical staff.

events.title: SDNY Tour of MCC Following Epstein's Death
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York schedules a tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center to inspect the suicide watch area, SHU, and Jeffrey Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: DOJ Statement on Epstein's Death
events.description: Attorney General William P. Barr issues an official statement on the death of Jeffrey Epstein, which is circulated internally within the Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Epstein reports right arm numbness
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein reports to Nurse Joseph Columbo that he woke up with no control over his right arm for a few minutes. He is evaluated, and the MD on call is notified.

events.title: Epstein's chronic care clinic evaluation
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin evaluates Jeffrey Epstein, who reports being without his medications for about a week, previous right arm numbness, sleep apnea without his CPAP machine, and other health issues. New medications and tests are ordered.

events.title: AP inquiry about MCC staff charges
events.description: Associated Press reporter Michael Sisak emails Adam Johnson, stating that two employees of the MCC are about to be charged regarding lapses the night of Jeffrey Epstein's death, and asks if Johnson is representing them.

events.title: Epstein refuses optometrist evaluation
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin documents that Jeffrey Epstein was offered an optometrist evaluation and refused, signing a refusal form.

events.title: Administrative note on inmate statement
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin notes that the MLP (Mid-Level Practitioner) notified the OP LT (Operations Lieutenant) of an inmate statement regarding 'what happened to him 2 nights ago.'

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injury in Cell
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He reported to medical staff he did not know how it happened, saying 'Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting'.

events.title: Follow-up Medical Visit and Cellmate Insinuation
events.description: During a follow-up visit, Epstein told provider Joaquin, 'I think my room mate had to do with what happened to me. Do not ask me. I am not going to say anything.' He still had erythema and abrasions on his neck.

events.title: Epstein's Intake Health Screening
events.description: Initial health screening conducted by PA-C Yoon Kang. Epstein reported medical history including hypertriglyceridemia, sleep apnea, and back pain. He also reported sexual history including 10+ female partners in the last 5 years and a prior chlamydia infection.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluations
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin conducted evaluations for Epstein's chronic conditions: hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, severe L4-L5 spinal stenosis causing back pain and numbness, and constipation. Medications were prescribed and follow-up scheduled.

events.title: Epstein Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes initial medical intake at MCC New York (NYM) by PA Yoon Kang. He is alert, oriented, and denies mental health issues or suicidal ideation. Vital signs show elevated blood pressure (164/90). Labs and an EKG are ordered.

events.title: Epstein Comprehensive History & Physical
events.description: MLP Y. Joaquin conducts a full History & Physical on Epstein. He reports being a banker, traveling to Paris for 3 weeks prior to arrest, having 10+ female sexual partners in the last 5 years, and a history of chlamydia in 2015. He denies abuse history. Vital signs are normal. He is prescribed bisacodyl for constipation.

events.title: Medrol Dose Pack Ordered for Back Pain
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin orders a Medrol Dose Pack for Epstein for shooting pain in the middle of his back.

events.title: Insulin and CPAP Machine Ordered
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin orders regular insulin via sliding scale twice daily for 7 days and issues a Philips Respironics CPAP machine to Epstein.

events.title: Incident Report for Tattooing/Self-Mutilation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was charged with BOP code 228 (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation), assigned incident report number 3282555. This led to a psychological competency evaluation.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein, where he denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or self-injurious behavior.

events.title: Follow-up Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Darlene Imeri conducted a suicide risk assessment, noting it was unclear if Epstein placed a string around his neck or if someone else did.

events.title: Psych Observation Discontinuation
events.description: After consultation with the Chief Psychologist, Dr. Imeri discontinued Epstein's psych observation status.

events.title: Dental Examination
events.description: Dr. Cheryl Ancrum performed a dental health history and A&O exam on Epstein, noting moderate to advanced upper posterior gingival recession.

events.title: Epstein Psychological Observation - Complaints about SHU
events.description: Epstein is seen by Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller. He is in good spirits but claims no memory of how he received marks around his neck. He complains extensively about SHU conditions, calling it a 'punishment cell,' and expresses a desire to be housed in general population.

events.title: Epstein Requests to Speak with Former Cellmate
events.description: Epstein is seen by Miller. He again states he has no memory of the event that caused scabbing on his neck. He asks to speak with his old cellmate 'Nick' to see if he can trigger his memory or provide information about what happened.

events.title: Epstein Reports Anxiety and Physical Symptoms
events.description: Epstein is seen by psychologist Darlene Imeri. He reports anxiety about returning to SHU, states he only slept 30 minutes per night there due to noise, and claims he cannot remember what caused the marks on his neck. He complains of dehydration and numbness.

events.title: Epstein Reports Aversive Reaction to Toilet Noise
events.description: Epstein is seen by Imeri. He reports an extremely aversive reaction to a malfunctioning toilet that flushed for 45 minutes, saying it left him agitated for hours. He compares the feeling to being in SHU and suggests he 'may have something on the Autism spectrum.' Medical is notified of ongoing numbness.

events.title: Epstein Requests to Stay in Hospital Area
events.description: Epstein is seen by Miller. He suggests his memory of the neck injury incident may be impaired due to sleep apnea. He requests to remain in the hospital area where he feels 'safe' for a week, but is told he will return to SHU the next day after receiving his CPAP machine.

events.title: String Incident and Suicide Watch Placement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch at 1:40 AM. The circumstances were unclear - Epstein claimed memory loss, while staff logs indicated he told inmate companions his cell mate tried to kill him.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: After psychological evaluation, Epstein was stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation. He adamantly denied suicidal ideation, expressed commitment to life, and was future-oriented about his legal case.

events.title: Placement in SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: SHU Review Attempt
events.description: Monthly SHU review attempted but Epstein was meeting with his legal team and had a court hearing, so interview was postponed.

events.title: Epstein returns from court proceeding
events.description: Epstein returned to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after a court proceeding in the evening, prompting staff to place him on precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment conducted
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Epstein at 7:30 AM, finding low acute risk and absent chronic risk.

events.title: Clinical intervention session
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation contact where he presented numerous concerns about his housing, medical needs, uniform, and requests for property and legal phone calls.

events.title: Upcoming bail hearing
events.description: Epstein mentioned he was looking forward to his bail hearing scheduled for Monday (July 15, 2019), though he acknowledged even if granted bail, it would take weeks to arrange his release.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding which potentially gave him 'bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting BOP psychology to implement precautionary monitoring.

events.title: Precautionary Psychological Observation Initiated
events.description: Upon Epstein's return from court, BOP staff were instructed to notify psychology and place him on a precautionary psychological observation status due to identified risk factors.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller conducted a formal suicide risk assessment interview with Epstein, finding him alert, cooperative, future-oriented, and denying any suicidal ideation. Acute risk was assessed as low.

events.title: Intake Screening and Sexual Abusiveness Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. K. Schlessinger conducted initial psychological intake and assessed Epstein's risk for sexual abusiveness in the prison setting, rating him as low risk.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported to the psychologist that he had a bail hearing scheduled for the upcoming Monday (July 12, 2019) and believed he would be released.

events.title: Blood Collection for Lab Work
events.description: Blood was collected from Jeffrey Epstein for comprehensive lab testing, including chemistry, hematology, and serology panels.

events.title: Refusal of Chest X-Ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refused a recommended routine chest X-ray, signing a treatment refusal form after being counseled by S. Esguerra.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin conducted a chronic care evaluation for Epstein, assessing hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and back pain, and prescribing medication (Vascepa).

events.title: Injury Assessment After Found with Rope
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (SHU Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck. He was assessed by MLP Y. Joaquin, who noted erythema on his neck and knee, and placed him on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical Records Request Email
events.description: Legal Assistant Joy Aassiddaa emailed Adam Johnson and Stephanie Scannell, attaching medical records for Jeffrey Epstein covering July 1-24, 2019.

events.title: Refusal of Eye Doctor Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refused a recommended eye doctor evaluation, signing a treatment refusal form after being counseled by Dr. Robert Beaudouin.

events.title: Epstein Initial Health Screen
events.description: Epstein undergoes initial health screening and intake evaluation by PA-C Yoon Kang at MCC New York, documenting his medical history, vital signs (elevated BP), and risk factors.

events.title: Epstein History & Physical Exam
events.description: Epstein receives a comprehensive History & Physical examination by MLP Y. Joaquin, documenting detailed review of systems, family history, and physical findings.

events.title: Epstein Chronic Care Evaluation
events.description: Epstein seen by Dr. Robert Beaudouin for chronic care evaluation, complaining of back pain, hyperlipidemia, and sleep apnea. Medications including Methylprednisolone and Magnesium Hydroxide are prescribed.

events.title: Epstein Medical Examination
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a physical examination at the Bureau of Prisons, where he refuses rectal and male genitalia exams, is diagnosed with constipation, and prescribed medication.

events.title: String Around Neck Incident
events.description: Epstein is found in his cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to placement on suicide watch. Medical records show a circular line around the base of his neck.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri conducts a suicide risk assessment after the string incident, noting Epstein denied remembering the event and that he told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Placed in Administrative Segregation
events.description: Epstein is placed in Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: Epstein returns from court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from court proceedings in the evening, leading to his placement on precautionary psychological observation status.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment
events.description: Formal suicide risk assessment conducted by Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller, determining Epstein had low acute suicide risk and no chronic risk.

events.title: Release from psychological observation
events.description: Epstein was assessed as psychologically stable and released from the psychological observation area to be housed in the 9S area with a cellmate.

events.title: Risk of Sexual Abusiveness Assessment
events.description: A psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein's risk of being sexually abusive within the prison, based on his history of sexual abuse perpetration in the community. He was rated as low risk.

events.title: Placement on Psychological Observation
events.description: Upon returning from court, Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation status due to identified risk factors for suicidality.

events.title: Psychological Intake Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes initial psychological screening at MCC-NY. He denies mental health history, substance abuse, or being a victim of abuse. He is assessed as Care Level 1 (no significant impairment).

events.title: Medical Lab Tests
events.description: Blood work is collected and shows high cholesterol, triglycerides, and hemoglobin A1c (6.3, indicating diabetes risk). Tests for HIV and RPR (syphilis) are negative.

events.title: Chronic Care Clinic Visits
events.description: Epstein is evaluated for multiple issues: numbness in his right arm, lack of medications for a week, hypertension, sleep apnea (no CPAP for 3 weeks), prediabetes, and other conditions. He is prescribed insulin.

events.title: Cardiac Arrest and Resuscitation
events.description: At approximately 06:35, a body alarm is activated. Epstein is found unresponsive on his cell floor, cold, with bruising around the neck and fixed, dilated pupils. CPR is performed, he is intubated, given epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate, and transported to a local ER with CPR in progress.

events.title: Medical Records Request
events.description: Legal Assistant Joy Aassiddaa emails Adam Johnson and Stephanie Scannell requesting Jeffrey Epstein's medical records for the period July 6, 2019, to August 28, 2019.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injury
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He reported waking up "snorting" and had circular erythema (redness) and abrasions on his neck. Custody staff reported it as a self-inflicted injury, and he was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Hints at Cellmate Involvement
events.description: During a follow-up exam, Epstein insinuated to MLP Joaquin that his cellmate "had to do with what happened to me" regarding his neck injury, but refused to elaborate further.

events.title: Epstein Reports Neurological Symptoms
events.description: Epstein reported to nursing staff that he woke up with a loss of control and numbness in his right arm for a few minutes, which he attributed to sleeping on his side. He was evaluated multiple times.

events.title: Comprehensive Medical Evaluation
events.description: Epstein underwent a chronic care clinic encounter where he reported multiple health issues including right arm numbness, lack of sleep, and being without medications for a week. New medications and diagnostic tests (labs, cervical spine X-ray) were ordered.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes his initial health screening at MCC New York conducted by PA-C Yoon Kang. His vital signs are taken, medical history is recorded, and initial lab tests are ordered.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin evaluates Epstein for chronic conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and severe back pain. Epstein reports his CPAP machine was with him when he was arrested and is now likely with the FBI.

events.title: Follow-up Chronic Care Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin conducts another evaluation of Epstein, noting similar complaints and ordering a 180-day supply of Vascepa for hyperlipidemia.

events.title: Medical Note Cosignature
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin cosigns a medical note from another provider (likely related to Epstein's care).

events.title: Epstein's Intake Medical Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a comprehensive medical and mental health intake screening at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The assessment finds him alert, oriented, and cooperative, with no signs of recent trauma, suicidal ideation, or acute mental health issues.

events.title: Initial PPD Test Administered
events.description: A tuberculin skin test (PPD) is administered to Epstein by PA-C Kang upon his entry into BOP custody. It is read on July 9, showing 0mm induration (negative).

events.title: CPAP Machine Issued and Fish Allergy Noted
events.description: Dr. Beaudouin issues a CPAP machine to Epstein for his sleep apnea and formally documents a dietary restriction due to fish allergies.

events.title: Medical Transfer Prepared
events.description: Nurse Columbo completes a 'Local Hospital Transfer' form summarizing Epstein's active health problems, medications, and restrictions, indicating preparations for a potential transfer.

events.title: Incident with Marks on Neck
events.description: An incident occurred where Epstein had marks on his neck, documented as 'R/O self inflicted injuries' in health records and referenced in a psychological assessment as an unclear event where a string was around his neck.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment Following Marshals Report
events.description: A suicide risk assessment was conducted by Dr. Imeri after US Marshals presented a form stating Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies' upon his return from court.

events.title: Psychological Follow-up Session
events.description: Dr. Miller conducted a follow-up clinical session with Epstein in the SHU. Epstein reported feeling okay, wanting to go to general population, and spending his days with his attorneys.

events.title: Initial Intake and Assessments
events.description: Epstein's initial medical and psychological intake at the MCC, including a suicide risk assessment by Dr. Miller, vision screen, immunizations, and education assessment.

events.title: Dental Health Assessment
events.description: Epstein received a comprehensive dental health history and examination by Dr. Cheryl Ancrum.

events.title: Epstein found with string around neck in SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found by staff in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember anything about it, leading to an incident report for tattooing/self-mutilation.

events.title: Competency evaluation for disciplinary process
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by psychologist Darlene Imeri for competency to proceed with the disciplinary process regarding the July 23 incident. He was found competent.

events.title: Follow-up after removal from Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was seen by psychologist Jolie Avena for a follow-up after being removed from Psychological Observation. He reported going to court for a status hearing and was assessed as stable.

events.title: Comprehensive suicide risk assessment
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri conducted a detailed suicide risk assessment, noting risk factors (high-profile crime, physical pain) and protective factors (future orientation, social support). Overall risk was assessed as low.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch following an incident in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) that resulted in marks and a scab around his neck. The exact nature of the incident is unclear.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Psychologist Samantha DiMisa completed a Post Suicide Watch Report, assessing Epstein's overall acute suicide risk as Low and chronic risk as Absent. He was stepped down to Psychological Observation.

events.title: Daily Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein remained on Psychological Observation from July 24-28, 2019, with daily evaluations by psychology staff. He was continuously observed by inmate companions and attended legal visits.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours, leading to his placement on suicide watch. The origin of the string (self-inflicted or by another) was unclear.

events.title: Placement in SHU (Administrative Segregation)
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on administrative detention status.

events.title: Missed SHU Review Due to Legal Meetings
events.description: A scheduled SHU review for Epstein could not be conducted because he was meeting with his legal team and had a court hearing.

events.title: Psychological assessments conducted
events.description: Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller conducted multiple psychological assessments of Jeffrey Epstein, including suicide risk assessment and diagnostic formulation, finding no mental health diagnosis and low suicide risk.

events.title: Assessment amendment
events.description: Miller amended the psychological assessment notes, with the amendment timestamped on July 10, 2019 at 09:20.

events.title: Previous incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reported having served time in Palm Beach County jail on sex offense charges (soliciting prostitution) prior to his current federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Epstein Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding which, according to the psychologist's note, could potentially be giving him bad news regarding his legal situation.

events.title: Psychological Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Epstein, concluding his overall acute suicide risk was low and chronic risk was absent.

events.title: Intake Screening and Risk Assessments
events.description: Psychologist K. Schlessinger conducted an intake screening and a Risk of Sexual Abusiveness assessment on Epstein upon his arrival at MCC-NY.

events.title: Medical Lab Work Drawn
events.description: Blood was drawn from Epstein for comprehensive chemistry, hematology, and serology tests, including HIV and RPR screening.

events.title: Epstein refuses chest x-ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refused a recommended routine chest x-ray at MCC New York, citing no prior medical history.

events.title: Epstein refuses rectal/genital exam
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refused a recommended rectal and genital examination at MCC New York.

events.title: Epstein refuses eye doctor evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein refused a recommended eye doctor evaluation at MCC New York on two separate occasions.

events.title: Epstein dental examination
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein received a dental examination at MCC New York, with intra-oral photos and radiographs taken.

events.title: New Hampshire Democratic Convention
events.description: The New Hampshire Democratic Party held its annual state convention where 19 presidential candidates spoke.

events.title: Third Democratic presidential debate
events.description: Upcoming Democratic presidential debate in Houston mentioned in the article, where Biden and Warren were set to face off.

events.title: Mark Sanford announces primary challenge
events.description: Former South Carolina Congressman Mark Sanford announced a Republican primary challenge against President Trump.

events.title: Afghanistan Peace Talks Collapse
events.description: Trump canceled secret meeting with Afghan and Taliban leaders at Camp David, exposing internal administration tensions.

events.title: Brexit Negotiations
events.description: Boris Johnson visited Dublin for talks with Irish leader Leo Varadkar on Northern Ireland Brexit issues.

events.title: Hurricane Dorian Aftermath
events.description: USAID administrator Mark Green toured disaster zones in the Bahamas where tens of thousands were homeless.

events.title: Hong Kong Protests
events.description: Thousands of demonstrators marched to U.S. Consulate seeking Washington's support for pro-democracy movement.

events.title: Congress Returns from Recess
events.description: Congress returned with agenda including government funding, gun restrictions, trade pact, and prescription drug pricing.

events.title: Publication of 'She Said'
events.description: New York Times reporters Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey publish a book detailing their investigation into Harvey Weinstein's sexual misconduct and the legal efforts to conceal it.

events.title: MIT Media Lab Scandal Erupts
events.description: Allegations surface that MIT Media Lab director Joi Ito sought to conceal donations from Jeffrey Epstein, leading to Ito's resignation and an external review ordered by MIT President L. Rafael Reif.

events.title: Epstein's $6.5 Million Donation to Harvard
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein made his largest gift to Harvard University, $6.5 million, for the Program for Evolutionary Dynamics.

events.title: Washington Post Daily 202 Newsletter
events.description: The Washington Post sends its 'The Daily 202' email newsletter summarizing news including #MeToo reporting on Weinstein and Epstein's university ties.

events.title: Third Democratic Presidential Debate
events.description: Upcoming Democratic presidential debate in Houston where Biden and Warren were scheduled to face off.

events.title: Biden Town Hall in New Castle, NH
events.description: Joe Biden held a town hall where he was questioned by a young environmental activist about attending a fundraiser co-hosted by a fossil fuel executive.

events.title: Trump Cancels Camp David Taliban Meeting
events.description: President Trump canceled a secret meeting planned with Afghan and Taliban leaders at Camp David, exposing internal administration divisions.

events.title: Mark Sanford Announces Primary Challenge
events.description: Former South Carolina congressman Mark Sanford announced a Republican primary challenge against President Trump.

events.title: MIT Media Lab Director Resigns Over Epstein Ties
events.description: MIT President L. Rafael Reif announced that Joi Ito resigned as director of the Media Lab over allegations of concealing donations from Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Inquiry on Epstein's Mental Capacity
events.description: Glenda Anderson-Layne sends an email inquiring whether inmate Jeffrey Epstein is mentally capable of proceeding with the disciplinary process.

events.title: Psychologist's Response
events.description: Elissa Miller, Chief Psychologist, responds to the inquiry about Epstein's mental capacity.

events.title: Post-Death Investigations Begin
events.description: FBI and OIG are notified and arrive at MCC New York to investigate. The body is released to the Medical Examiner. A Crisis Support Team is activated and later debriefed.

events.title: OIG Removes Computers
events.description: OIG Agents John Kerwin and Guido Modano arrive, and Kerwin departs with two computers from the institution.

events.title: Staff Recall and FBI Visits
events.description: A staff recall is conducted. The FBI arrives and departs multiple times throughout the day and evening.

events.title: Senior BOP Officials Arrive
events.description: Senior BOP officials, including the NER Correctional Services Administrator, National suicide prevention coordinator, National Sex offender program coordinator, and Northeast Regional Director, arrive at the institution.

events.title: Email Sent Regarding Prior Observation
events.description: An email with the subject 'Psych Observation 7/8/19 6 pm until 7/10/19 at 9 am re: Epstein, Jeffrey' was created and sent, documenting the prior event.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was on psychological observation at MCC New York from July 24 to July 30, 2019, with a log tracking his basic activities.
The document shows routine BOP operations, including scheduling a telephonic court hearing for another inmate, Wilbert Kitson Turner, highlighting the facility's procedures.
Associate Warden Charisma Edge is identified as a point of contact at MCC New York.
The email chain demonstrates coordination between BOP staff attorneys and private defense attorneys to facilitate legal access for inmates.
The psychological observation log for Epstein is attached to an email dated August 12, 2019, indicating it was being circulated internally after his death.
Inmate Nicholas 'Nick' Turner was placed in the SHU at MCC-NY in July 2019 over an alleged cell phone possession.
Turner's attorney, Bruce Barket, complained of deplorable conditions in the SHU cell, including a leaking toilet, wet floor, and lack of personal property like books and a radio.
Barket raised a serious concern that privileged attorney-client work product documents were seized from Turner when he was moved to SHU and had not been returned.
A status conference for Turner's civil case (Turner v. Ulloa, et al.) was rescheduled from August 9, 2019, to August 8, 2019, by Judge Lisa Margaret Smith.
The email correspondence shows coordination between MCC legal staff (Adam Johnson, Stephanie Scannell) and federal prosecutors (Jason Swergold, Michael Gerber) regarding Turner's situation.

An inmate named 'Nick' was placed in the SHU at the MCC in early July 2019 for alleged cell phone possession, and his attorney complained about poor conditions including a leaking toilet and seizure of privileged legal work.
In August 2019, Jeffrey Epstein's attorney contacted the MCC to help Epstein establish a telephone account, indicating the process had been started but not completed.
On August 12, 2019, Attorney General William Barr announced investigators were finding 'serious irregularities' at the federal lockup where Epstein died.
A news article from August 19, 2019, reported Epstein signed a will worth $577 million just two days before his suicide.
The email chain shows coordination between BOP legal staff, federal prosecutors, and defense attorneys regarding inmate conditions and procedural issues at the MCC.
Jeffrey Epstein signed a will worth $577 million just two days before his suicide on August 10, 2019.
One witness to Epstein's will was Mariel Colon Miro, a lawyer who had represented Mexican drug lord El Chapo.
Video surveillance footage from the time of Epstein's first suicide attempt in July 2019 was reported missing.
Internal BOP emails discuss arranging a visit for the U.S. Attorney's Office to inspect Epstein's cell and the psych observation area at the MCC.
A separate email references a 'Psych Observation' report for Epstein dated July 24-30, 2019, with an attachment that is part of the document set.
Jeffrey Epstein was on a formal psychology observation/suicide watch from July 24 to July 30, 2019, while incarcerated.
The observation log includes detailed tracking of his meals, liquid intake, showers, and general behavior.
An 'I/M companion' (inmate companion) was utilized during this observation period, indicating he was not left alone.
The log was officially forwarded via email on August 12, 2019, by Associate Warden Charisma Edge to other Bureau of Prisons officials.
The document is part of the official prison recordkeeping procedures prior to Epstein's death in August 2019.
Jeffrey Epstein (Registration No. 73618-054) was placed on psychological observation/suicide watch from July 24 to July 30, 2019.
The document includes a detailed log tracking Epstein's meals, liquid intake, showers, and behavioral observations during this period.
An email dated August 12, 2019, was sent to transmit this observation log, indicating official record-keeping of his status in custody.

A separate email chain discusses a court order (Case 1:15-cr-00537) requiring a mental health treatment update for inmate Anthony Scott by March 10, 2020.
BOP legal staff coordinate internally on how to respond to the court order, deciding to contact AUSA Samson Enzer directly.
The document includes contact information for Associate Warden Charisma Edge.
The email is dated January 8, 2020, and involves BOP staff at the Devens facility.

A group of federal prosecutors from the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office, including Geoffrey Berman and Audrey Strauss, requested a visit to the MCC in August 2019 to inspect areas related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, including his still-cordoned-off cell.
The visit request specified that only MCC legal staff should escort the prosecutors and that they would not speak to any guards due to ongoing investigations.
The document shows internal BOP legal email correspondence regarding a court order in an unrelated criminal case (USA v. Conyers et al), indicating routine legal operations within the BOP.
The email regarding the MCC visit is dated August 13, 2019, shortly after Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, suggesting it was part of the immediate post-death investigative activities.
SDNY prosecutors requested a detailed visit to the MCC, including Epstein's cell and suicide watch areas, shortly after his death, indicating an active investigation.
An Associated Press reporter indicated in November 2019 that two MCC employees were 'about to be charged' for lapses related to Epstein's death.
A major Miami Herald investigation revealed systemic sexual abuse of female inmates by male officers at the Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, leading to a lawsuit.
Internal BOP emails show officials were caught off guard by the abuse report and scrambled to compile sexual abuse allegation statistics from 2014-2019.
The BOP's response to the abuse allegations explicitly links the dysfunction to the high-profile death of Jeffrey Epstein at another BOP facility.
BOP Office of Internal Affairs data shows hundreds of staff/inmate sexual abuse allegations annually from FY2014-2019, with charges sustained in fewer than 5% of cases.

A Miami Herald investigation alleged systemic sexual abuse by male officers at the women's camp of Coleman Federal Correctional Complex, leading to a lawsuit by 14 women.
